oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Gov. Bob Taylor, Lecturer

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Advertisement for a lecture by three-term governor Bob Taylor to be held at the Opera House. A publicity photo of Taylor occupies most of the space, with the notation that the event is produced under the exclusive direction of the Rice Bureau.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Broadsides; Announcements; Handbills; Fliers (printed matter); Portrait photographs; Publicity photographs
Broadsides; Lectures and lecturing; Taylor, Robt. L. (Robert Love), 1850-1912; Rice, DeLong, 1872-1929
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: The Rice Bureau
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: DeLong Rice was deeply inspired when he heard Bob Taylor speak in 1888. A business association ensued, leading to Rice's management of Taylor's lecture tours beginning in 1891. Taylor quickly became the highest-priced professional lecturer in the country. Rice organized his Rice Lyceum Bureau in 1900 and staged high-quality lecture and entertainment tours across the South. Such cultural events served as an educational resource for the audience.
